Latvia's best player is Kristers Tobers is a Latvian footballer who plays as a defensive midfielder or central defender. Born on December 13, 2000, Tobers has been a prominent figure in the Latvian national team, known for his defensive solidity, ability to intercept balls and his versatility on the field. He began his career with FK Liepāja, one of Latvia's top clubs, before moving to Lechia Gdańsk in Poland, where he has continued to develop his skills. Tobers is considered one of the most promising young talents in Latvian soccer, with a bright future both for his national team and at club level.

Eduard Spertsyan is an Armenian footballer who has gained recognition as one of the most promising talents of the Armenian national team. Born on June 7, 2000 in Krasnodar, Russia, he plays as an attacking midfielder and is known for his technique, dribbling ability and ability to create attacking moves. Since his debut with FC Krasnodar in the Russian Premier League, he has proven to be a key player for both his club and the Armenian national team. Spertsyan has scored important goals and has been a key player in Armenia's bid to improve its performance in international competitions.

Needing a win to stand any chance of continuing their campaign at Euro 2024, Croatia meet Group B rivals Italy in Leipzig on Monday evening.
Two disappointing displays have left the Vatreni with only one point on the board, so head coach Zlatko Dalic is sure to rotate his resources in search of a quick change in fortunes.
Though Nikola Vlasic left the squad last week due to a muscular injury, Dalic has each of his remaining 25 men available to take on the reigning European champions.

Substituted at half time in the 2-2 draw with Albania, midfield fulcrum Marcelo Brozovic may now be dropped to the bench, allowing an opportunity for RB Salzburg prospect Luka Sucic or even Dinamo Zagreb's Martin Baturina to start instead.
Either international rookie would line up alongside long-term fixtures Luka Modric and Mateo Kovacic, both of whom have won over 100 caps for their nation.

Meanwhile, up front, Bruno Petkovic missed a penalty against Spain and then made way for Ante Budimir midway through the second half against Albania, so the latter could be promoted to the starting XI.

After switching from left-back to the heart of Croatia's defence last time out, Josko Gvardiol is set to continue in his preferred role; ever versatile, Ivan Perisic filled in at full-back, but Borna Sosa may now win the fight for selection.
Croatia and Italy meet to conclude their UEFA EURO 2024 Group B campaigns on Monday 24 June.
Coaches Zlatko Dalić and Luciano Spalletti both have plenty to ponder going into this pivotal Matchday 3 fixture.

The Azzurri were also given a fright by Albania in their opening game – conceding inside 23 seconds – before recovering to win 2-1, though the holders had no answer to Spain next time out.
